title: Rigoletto, Glyndebourne, review: a new production with good singing but unsubtle acting – and why the incest?
text:
A rigorous feminist perspective might regard Verdi’s Rigoletto as the tale of a 17-year-old virgin, Gilda, kept locked up by her paranoid father, Rigoletto, only to be raped by a man she mistakenly believes to be her sincere lover and, as a result, lose her self-respect to the point that she sacrifices her life to save his.

This approach could have theatrical potency, and it wouldn’t be altogether reductive. But although she’s clearly aware of the abuse of women that the plot implies, Christiane Lutz – one of the first female directors to stage this opera – draws back in her new Glyndebourne production, seeming more interested in the plight of the father than the daughter.
